text:
is there code for something like
```@variables x y z
v = variety([y-x^2, z-x^3])
plot(v)```
i'd like to build some plot recipes if this doesn't already exist

elements.text: is there code for something like
i'd like to build some plot recipes if this doesn't already exist

text: I don’t think that exists. That would be great!

elements.text: I don’t think that exists. That would be great!

text: I wrote some code to plot plane curves <https://github.com/saschatimme/ImplicitPlots.jl> . There is also some code in the source for 3d stuff but this bitrotted due to updates in AbstractPlotting.

elements.text: I wrote some code to plot plane curves
. There is also some code in the source for 3d stuff but this bitrotted due to updates in AbstractPlotting.

text: But I didn't find an easy way for space curves (which your example is one)

elements.text: But I didn't find an easy way for space curves (which your example is one)

text: In that particular case it’s just a parametrised curve, but of course that’s not usually the case

elements.text: In that particular case it’s just a parametrised curve, but of course that’s not usually the case

text: thanks! btw the docs for homotopy continuation are amazing, thanks for making it so accessible! do yall know how the authors generated this plot then? is this something that mathematica/other cas systems have?

elements.text: thanks! btw the docs for homotopy continuation are amazing, thanks for making it so accessible! do yall know how the authors generated this plot then? is this something that mathematica/other cas systems have?

text: I'm pretty sure that Mathematica can draw plots like that though that particular one doesn't immediately look like Mathematica to me

elements.text: I'm pretty sure that Mathematica can draw plots like that though that particular one doesn't immediately look like Mathematica to me

text: Is there a way to automatically parametrise space curves?

elements.text: Is there a way to automatically parametrise space curves?

text: I guess as most symbolic computations a combination of groebner bases and elimination :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I guess as most symbolic computations a combination of groebner bases and elimination

text: How much of that is available in Julia?

elements.text: How much of that is available in Julia?

text: I looked a little bit more into this, and all these seems rather involved. I guess figuring out a way to intersect two surfaces would be much easier

elements.text: I looked a little bit more into this, and all these seems rather involved. I guess figuring out a way to intersect two surfaces would be much easier

text: (if it is only for visualisation purposes)

elements.text: (if it is only for visualisation purposes)

text: You can do this with IntervalConstraintProgramming, but the problem is that it just gives a collection of boxes, rather than a curve. It can still look decent, though

elements.text: You can do this with IntervalConstraintProgramming, but the problem is that it just gives a collection of boxes, rather than a curve. It can still look decent, though
